The following should work (not necessarily the best way to do it but 
should work):

Sum the product of the enthalpy_mole (or enthalpy_mass) multiplied by 
X (or Y) for each of the reactant species at your initial T and P. 
Repeat the process for the products. The difference is the energy 
change of the system.

How you get the products is up to you. For instance, if you have a 
constant temperature, constant pressure process reaching equilibrium 
you can use the "equilibrate" function with the 'TP' flag set. If 
you're using frozen chemistry you'll have to find mass or mole 
fractions through rate reactions that you manually stop.

Good luck.
Chad

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, Surinder Prabhjot Singh 
<prabhjot102@y...> wrote:
> 
> Hello,
> My question is related to constant temperature
> process. I  know we can carry out a reaction at
> constant temperature if we set energy="off" in a
> reactor so that the energy equations are not
> integrated. But my question is how do I calculate the
> total energy change in a constant temperature process.
> I need to calculate the total energy evolved if I
> carry out a certain reaction at constant temperature?
> 
> Surinder
